text: hi thanks for coming along to uh The Talk today it's about the Geeks guide to Leading teams now what I find
interesting is that in our industry we have a lot of people who can talk about the sort of technical practices that we
as developers need to get good at doing so we have books on refactoring we have people who can teach us how to write
clean code we have a lot of things to talk us about continuous integration and now continuous delivery but what about
when we have to work with teams and work with people so if you've been working in industry for a while as a developer most
organizations you'll end up working with a team and most likely you'll end up in a leadership position and what I want to
share during this presentation are really some of the things that I've learned uh working with lots of different teams and then moving into a
leadership position and some of the skills and some of the things that you need to think about to help you prepare
because there's nothing really out there that can kind of help us so before we kind of begin you
probably want to know well who am I um and a little bit about my back my background is well I'm a programmer at
heart so most of the time I I work for a consultancy and I work with projects delivering software uh as part of my
role I often end up as a team lead um and so I end up helping big teams kind of work and deliver projects for clients
at the same time I'm very passionate about agile uh and I really am enthused about the way that's kind of working uh
and as Linda mentioned uh I recently published a book called The retrospective handbook because for me
it's very essential uh to be learning and understanding how we improve our practice practices I've been working
with teams for about 6 to seven years uh as a team lead and a lot of the stuff I'll talk about are these experiences
that I've kind of thought about over the time but if you if you're kind of are working in different environments you
might be thinking about well why is it that we need a team lead so why is it that we need somebody from a technical
perspective to lead a team now I think about myself about when I first started programming I I joined a small group of
people I was actually the only developer on the team so you end up with this sort of one target and it's just you and
yourself perhaps you've been in a situation like this before um and when you're thinking about what you need to
deliver it seems trivially easy there's just this one thing and we end up heading towards that Target pretty easy
right now in most organizations today if you think about Google that little search box there's obviously a large
organization behind it and so we can't really do things by ourselves anymore these days because of the scale of the
things that we need to actually achieve so we end up working with a much larger team of some sort and we have to work in
these boundaries and we have to understand what that is we still have this goal that we'd like to achieve but
now we have a lot more people that we need to think about so what happens is well you know we kind of end up wanting
to head towards this Target and conceptually everyone should know where this target is and is starting to head
in that same path now in reality what kind of happens is you do start off with
this Target and you start off with this group of people and you kind of end up starting on this path but maybe what
happened happens over time is that people kind of end up going in different directions who's been in a situation
like this who actually you know have worked on a project that doesn't actually know what they're there to
do I've certainly been in places like that where you know you're there as a developer but you don't really know what
product and and perhaps the vision isn't so clear from the product owner and so there's a lot of confusion around it so
it creates chaos it creates anger and as a developer I know this is that if I write something and it doesn't get used
I get frustrated ated and it feels like a bit of a waste so we all want to be kind of doing really well so I think uh
it's it's a really important thing to think about particularly being a tet lead and if you don't think this really happens in the real world I uh I have a
good friend uh called Julian on Twitter and he had this quote that I really love I had 10 guys on my last project
all of them had opinions and all of them were expressed in the code base so if you think about Conway's law
in 10 different ways of working you're end up with 10 different parts of the code base and if somebody new comes onto
the project or wants to change something else you're kind of stuck and so for me I have a very simple test um for what is
an effective Tech lead and it looks like this does the code base look like it was
written by a single person so if you think about that sort of a first picture where we thought about one person and
that Target if you opened up random parts of the code base does it feel the same sort of patterns are there does it
feel consistent and for me this is one of the key responsibilities of TCH lead is to really help Shepherd people towards that
goal to help set that Vision that direction and to make sure people end up
going in that direction and throughout this talk we'll kind of talk about the different elements it takes to get to
that point where it looks like a single person wrote the code base now it doesn't happen in reality but it's a
nice simple test to think about do we have consistency in what we're actually doing
so the next question I really want to answer is what does a good Tech lead focus on and for me there are kind of
three elements that I think about and as a developer when you're moving into this role there are two that maybe you kind
of have thought about but haven't given a lot of time on so the three elements that I'm kind of thinking about start
with p uh conveniently the first one is obviously elements of programming what
makes the difference between a technical leader and a team leader is that somebody who was a tech lead has experience in programming and still has
that experience and so they're an active developer I'll talk about that a bit more the second element uh that we'll be
talking about is about the people Dimension so as a developer and I I I know this I've been through this myself
is that you you're focused on this small little area of the code that you're currently working on you're not really
thinking necessarily about the team the groups of people that you're working with and the people that you have to interact with as well as the
relationships be between them this is an element we'll focus on in the second part and finally when I talk about
process it's a terrible word but it started with a p uh it's kind of really thinking about how do the people and the
programming sort of work together and uh if I think about life cycles of teams and various things like that um we're
going to be looking at well how does that work as a team process so the first part is going to be
exploring what is the programming elements of what a tech needs to do and the first question a lot of people ask
uh do effective technical leaders need to still code my answer to this is a
definite yes now the next question I guess is well how much should they code
If you're sort of working with a large team it's going to be a little bit hard to be coding every day just like everyone else so what's the right
balance and I have a bit of a a rule of thumb that I have here which is at least I think you need 30% of your time with
the team writing code so this means out of a 5-day week you need to be writing code at least one and a half days out of
that five week with the rest of the team now why does this actually make sense um I I think there's an
interesting article here uh it's called the unspoken truth about managing Geeks
uh when you look at the slides there's a link here anyway um and basically this article or the author of the article is
kind of talking about what is it that Geeks kind of how do you get along with geeks his perspective is a little bit
more in terms of the context of product owners and the business and working with developers um but in it he he writes
this quote respect is the currency of the realm so imagine yourself on a
development team working with other developers and you know that there's somebody over there who's not really pulling their weight they kind of you
know surf the Internet they might do their own little side projects what do you do you probably get really
frustrated if a if you've been in a situation like this you kind of maybe they're not really helping with you with
you sort of develop projects and uh actually write code that helps but he goes on to say the amount of respect an
IT Pro pays someone is a measure of how tolerable that person is when it comes to getting
things done who feels this way okay well when you think about it
for me it really rung true with how I seem to see how things work if you know
about our industry technology changes all the time we are hearing about new languages coming out one coming out this
uh afternoon at the last keynote uh and there's always new things to learn and so we can't really be exceptional at
everything that we do however we don't really like to work with people who make our job harder so if you have people who
aren't necessarily good or or make your job a lot harder it's very hard to understand what that means and as a tech
lead I think it's very hard to make the right decisions or to understand what the team is going through unless you're
actually part and you're going through that experience yourself so I think one of the biggest things that you need to
have as a tech lead is a rapport with the developers and the rest of the project uh and in order to do that I
feel that you actually need to be coding with them so you need to understand what the problems that they're experiencing are you can't just listen to what people
are saying you actually have to experience it yourself at the same time you also have to have a certain amount
of competence that you need to demonstrate to the rest of the people because if you're going to lead a team they need to have confidence in your own
ability and therefore you need to be able to demonstrate some of this so 30%
time you need to be coding with the team so that you can help build that respect and that you are actually part of that
team as well the next principle I have uh for um
leading development teams is really one about consistency over cleverness so as many as much as I like
using the latest uh tool the latest language uh that's really great if
you're a single developer but when you're actually thinking about an entire team and the and the sort of One
Direction that everyone's heading in what I'm actually prioritizing as a t lead is actually consistency because one
of the problems that um you you generally have in sort of software teams is that you have a bit of a churn uh and
even if you don't have churn you might end up with people with specialized knowledge in different parts of the code base and so if you go back to that whole
principle of trying to understand does the code base look like it was written by a single person you're really aiming
for consistency rather than clever code that kind of hides stuff away now one of the interesting things
is that when we talk about consistency over cleverness people who are actually trying to do clever things are actually
trying to do the right thing this is the whole retrospective prime directive they really want to do and learn the latest things and want to apply it and make
things simpler but sometimes as developers we get caught up in our arguments over what is best and
unfortunately I don't think there is a best thing in our sort of uh industry there's always contextual best in terms
of you need to understand what is good in your environment and what's suitable and so in many teams that I've joined uh
there's often these debates tabs or spaces no no no we need four spaces two spaces we need semi uh
we need curly braces on the next line or the or the one before um do we use camel case for underscore notation all of
these little arguments and you watch refactoring battles go on in the code base where people check stuff out
refactor stuff check it back in and really you know a lot of this stuff is a bit of a waste of time so my whole thing
that I talk to people about is that I think it's really important that we have consistency over cleverness because
there are more important topics to spend our time on there are actually technically uh challenging Pro problems
that we should be spending our uh sort of efforts on exploring on investigating and trying to come up with Creative
Solutions rather than arguing for our own personal
preference when it comes to programming I also think there's an element to team culture that we need to think about and
I'll talk about the people side a little bit later but this is really about what is the team culture around around the programming elements of how do people
treat uh the development aspects so for instance one of the things I think uh about when you need to build a team
culture is sort of thinking about a team charter of of how you work really um and
one of the things that I kind of well these sets of questions are the things that I kind of think about when I think about how healthy is a team when it
comes to technical progress so one thing is how long does the build Stay broken
so do we have a healthy culture of any one can actually fix the build regardless of whether or not they
thought they checked it in or do we get into entire arguments around I didn't do that checkin it's not my test that broke
um what's that team culture around keeping that build healthy and green hopefully we all have
builds the next thing is do people avoid conflict so do people do that whole
checkout refactor checkin rather than actually saying hey you know I think we have a bit of a disagreement about our
approach to this can we actually deal with and have a conversation about it so
I think conflict in teams is essential to actually healthy teams I think there's a bit of a a um you know picture
perfect team where everyone's smiling getting along and actually I think that's a bit of a dream I think it's healthy that teams have conflicts what's
important is as a tech lead you need to facilitate them through that conflict so you actually get to a answer of some
sort uh and I'll talk about the importance of conflict and why that's that's useful later the other thing is do people offer
new ideas yes I think as a um as a lead one of the things that I look for is
really creating an environment where people feel that they can actually fail failure is important uh Linda would have
talked about in her last uh talk uh where actually the whole uh human
mindset of learning and and trying something else is about failure we need an opportunity to feel that we are safe
to fail and as much as I hate being wrong in front of my team I'll be one of the first people to actually say hey I
tried something I got it wrong and we should move on and try something else and I wonder how many people feel
that they could actually do this in their teams right now and how safe does that environment
feel do people flag when they need help do you have people who go off uh in a
corner for for a week saying oh no no it'll be done it's 90% done it's almost done um and actually I heard of a story
about this recently from uh um some some ex colleagues of mine they're working with a small company where everyone's
working in teams of two to three people um and they had one person on on this team who had sort of broken away and
they were doing a a new API for integration um and it was supposed to be
done in two weeks it's been six months it's quite a while and each week people
are asking do you need help and he's kind of got into this reinforcing cycle where it's like no no I'm almost done I
don't need help I'm almost done uh and I think one of the things as a tech lead is that you need to be able to get help
people come out of stuff as humans we have personal Pride that's completely understandable however we need to be
able to accept that we make mistakes and we need to get through that so these are some of the things that I think really
make a big difference to our programming sense because other people have skills that we don't have that we can tap into
to help solve the problems that we can't necessarily by ourselves and so we need to we need to know when we need to ask
for help finally do people feel okay to admit that they're wrong uh and I think
there is a lot of stuff in developer circles about developer Pride uh and so think about the sort of environment that
you're you're sort of fostering and thinking about whether or not people can actually answer yes to these
questions the next thing I think is a tech lead that you need to focus on from a programming sense is a vision who's
heard of the XP practice the metaphor okay it was one of the uh XP
Edition one it got dropped in the second edition and for me it's actually really interesting thing because uh I don't
maybe necessarily understand it as much as Kent Beck does but for me I think it's a really powerful thing is that can
you actually articulate why your project or your uh software exists what is the problem that that's trying to solve and
why is it important um as a developer I think we all get kicks out of seeing the stuff
that we create get used there's nothing more uh um uh I don't know disappointing
than writing software that gets thrown away or features that never get used you kind of end up quite frustrated because
it feels like you've spent a lot of effort to no avail and so as a tech lead one of the things I think about
constantly is what is it that people need to hear to help them understand why they're here to do what they need to do
and if the answer is actually you need to cancel your project maybe that's a good thing I think it's important that
people have a compelling vision and a a purpose in programming there are so many things that shouldn't be sort of written
that can be done through manual uh sort of tasks and manual process that we shouldn't be writing software for and we
should be writing things that really add value and so for me the vision perspective is really important to what we're doing as
programmers so let's move on to the people aspect and and and here's kind of where we stray away from maybe a little
bit more of the classical stuff you hear in other talks um one of the things I think about is that there's something
about strength in diversity um one of the things I do with a lot of the teams and the people that I
work with is I I help people introduce this book called the strength finder book have many people heard of
this okay maybe one or two so for me it's really interesting because this book premise is as people we tend to
focus or at least our our sort of Education teaches us to focus on weaknesses we can't have any weaknesses
we have to get be good at everything unfortunately what they found out through a lot of research is that we're
much better if we focus on our strengths so I mean we have weaknesses and we should address them if they become sort
of problematic but we are much more successful if we know our strengths and if we focus on applying those strengths
in all the things that we do so this book talks about I think it's 34 different signature themes that and they
come up with about five different strengths so they talk about what are your top five signature strengths that kind of come through so I picked out a
few that maybe make sense to people in a sort of software context so maybe one of the things is
intellection so maybe you've worked with a developer like this who likes to think about a problem very deeply they like to
research do a lot of reading they like to think about the problem very deeply they want to think about what's the
right thing and think about other alternatives on the flip side you might have somebody who's uh an achiever so
somebody who just needs to get stuff done somebody who wants to see stuff out there and get stuff done
quickly and both of these things are very important in different different context of where we work in software
teams so sometimes we do need to push very quickly to get something out there but sometimes we have those really
challenging problems that need a lot of thought and one of the things that I really appreciate being a tech lead is
that in a team of people you have a much broader set of strengths than you do as an individual and so understanding each
of the different strengths of each person in your team makes you aware of at least where uh when different tasks
come up what makes sense to actually apply in different contexts so woo is really powerful when you actually need
to work with business people who don't don't like to talking to technical people you need somebody to win people
over so that they can open up to listening to why we might need to address architectural changes and why
they might need to invest in operational infrastructure or monitoring or various things that perhaps they don't really
make sense and so by understanding the people in your team and the strengths that they have you actually end up with
a much stronger sort of group overall than if you were doing it individually so one of the things that I
think is is really powerful in this book is that you can sort of uh get everyone a copy of the book and then work through
them with their uh strengths and help them talk to each other about what their strengths are if anything I think it
also helps everyone understand when everyone's like working closely together on the ground where each person is
coming from I know I've certainly been a lot less frustrated by people who maybe need ideation so they're they're looking
at the latest and greatest things all the time instead of actually getting stuff done because that's you know what
are the things that they're very good at and you know maybe when you're actually looking at new areas to sort of in some
some sort of uh feature that you've never dealt with before maybe they're the right person to help look at what
are the different options out there that can help us achieve that new goal so different contexts different
strengths and if you don't believe me I think there's some interesting uh statistics and research out there and
one of the things that I I really appreciate working at our company is we really value diversity so uh I think
pretty much on the last uh um six years I've worked on a project uh where
there's at least been one one female developer Vel er um on our sort of project and I know of a lot of people in
our industry who've never worked with a female developer and I think it's really interesting that there's a paper here that said that with three or more women
on the board they gain significant performance uh advantage over those with the fewest and if you look at the
statistics like in terms of actual monetary return that's pretty amazing um
this was a bit of an older paper but there was a more recent one over the past six years companies with at least
some so that means just one or more female board representative outperformed
those with no women on the board and those with uh just men had 12% return on
equity on their board those with women had 16% so that's a third more and I think
it's very interesting because once again the the sort of male female thing it is about diversity is about uh tapping into
things about the way that people think differently the different skills that they bring and uh there's a really good
book called the difference it's written by Scott page who's a Lector at the University of Michigan that actually has
done a lot of research in terms of proving and he got an amazing mathematical formula about improving how
diversity makes sense he has this formula and this isn't the mathematical version but he talks about Collective
accuracy equals the average accuracy plus the diversity in that
group who's heard of the Netflix uh challenge okay maybe one or two so it's
quite an old thing now I think it started in uh 2006 but uh Netflix is
that uh I think everyone at least knows the company because uh there's a few speakers from there um but they had a
competition where they basically wanted to improve their recommendation algorithm and so in 2006 they set out
this competition uh and Scott writes about it in his book where the people that could actually improve their
recommendation engine by 10% would win $1 million pretty pretty cool huh um and
what they did was that uh it had to be by at least 10% and for each year where
um people didn't achieve that they would have a nominated prize of 50,000 so people could submit their sort of
entries and what was really interesting wasn't the fact that they actually got to their 10% Improvement it was actually
interesting about how the teams and how they work together in terms of winning the actual outcome so in 2007 there were
three leading teams Bell cor uh big chaos and bellore in big chaos which was
actually a joint Union and all of them were doing pretty well but it was the joint Union that was doing a little bit
better than everyone else in 2009 uh one of the teams so uh Bor in
big chaos joined up with yet another group and that became I have to write it down because I can never remember it Bor
pragmatic chaos in order to improve their recommendation engine even more
and so they actually hit the 10% at that point but at the same time they had another competing team who hit
10.09 um called The Ensemble uh which was also a group of different people who had competed and
what was really interesting is that uh the final winner was actually an amalgamation of all the different people that got together rather than the
individuals who started off and what's fascinating about this is that it's actually a little bit of a um you know
it's a it's a real good example of this where their solution improved overall because they were able to integrate all
the different ways and different algorithms that they had together in order to improve their recommendation engine um and i' I'd really recommend
this book for going into a bit more detail about why diversity matters so when you're thinking about software and
the problems that we deal with as a tech lead it's really important to value and appreciate the diversity of the group
that you have and what what is really key is this the small star that I have on the slide which is you need that
ability to integrate so you need everyone to be able to work together in order to tap into this diversity there's
no sense in having a group of six people if all they do is work by themselves all the time because you're not actually
integrating all their Solutions
I think one of the other things about people is that as humans we're we're sort of built into this mode of working
in small groups and one of the things I think a lot a lot of companies do is send people out on trust building
activity days um and I would actually say don't do that trust isn't built in a
day I I've seen a lot of teams who go away have a lot of fun you know they do something outdoors and as a group but at
the end of the day when they come back into their working envir they're no better off trusting each other uh and
one of the sort of secret things that I've learned over time is actually trust is built very incrementally so the
things that you can do to help sort of shape some of this stuff is like you know make people to go out to lunch
together like don't force them but create opportunities to go to go and sit down to lunch together to spend social
time together um I I live in London and one of the biggest things there is actually making tea for each other
British people love their tea I'm originally Australian so I had to get into this whole tea making culture and
one of the things that uh they have in in the mornings and the afternoons is they have rounds of tea and so you're kind of making tea for each other and
you get to know what what each person has um and just the small token acts of actually doing these things for each
other is really important we live kind of in a very gift economy in terms of the way that we give and receive trust
is that if I do something for you I build a lot of trust um in terms of you know reciprocation and that's just kind
of how we're actually built so I think one of the key takeway I'd like you to think about is if you really want teams
to get together don't think about Big Bang things think about the small activities that happen daily that help
people grow stronger relationships together I think the the next thing as a
tet lead um that you need to think about from a people perspective is really thinking about how do you grow the
people on your team um and I really like this kind of model uh if you think about
uh when you're picking something up new for the first time so on the uh axis over there we have how difficult is a
challenge and on the bottom axis we have this thing about skill and ability uh and one of the things about
this kind of model um is that if we're given something too challenging but we don't have the skills for we get really
nervous we get really like you know we get the sweats we're thinking about I'm not so sure I can do this I get really
anxious about this sort of stuff at the same time if we're really good at something and we're not given anything
stimulating and the challenge is too easy for us we get bored and there's this thing where we kind of flow between
these two sort of uh things and The Sweet Spot that you kind of are thinking about is this section in the Middle
where you know we want something a little bit above our ability so that we can actually grow and challenge us but
we don't want it too much because we might get really stressed out at the same time we don't really want to be at this place here where we're kind of
bored and so when I'm thinking about the sort of different tasks that need to be done uh in or the different development
activities where skills lie in our sort of collective group of developers um one of the things I'm thinking about is how
do I match up somebody's skills and challenges so one of the things I like doing is actually having one-on ones
with people and asking people about you know what are their goals and what do they want to do uh and I get a good
sense about you know where they currently sit to help understand what are the things that are coming up um so
one of the things that you can then do is that you can give somebody a challenge that's a little bit outside of their current skill set and you can
support them in doing that sort of stuff um but one of the things you have to realize with this uh model is that
humans learn and we get better at stuff which is an amazing thing um but what that means is that we kind of end up
sort of going back into this sort of thing so once we get into that challenge we get into this flow you feel that
adrenaline hit from solving something and get excited um but you know if we're given that task for too long you know we
might end up getting bored so we always have this constant battle that we thinking about is that as we get
challenged and we overcome that we then face another thing where we need something more challenging than that to
keep us engaged and so it's a little bit of a cyclic thing um that becomes very hard
to actually sort of uh think about and it's it's a constantly evolving thing and the great thing about the industry
that we're in is that we have lots of problems to solve so there's lots of things for people to think about and lots of opportunities to grow the
challenge is as a lead trying to work with a team and help them identify what makes sense for them and how they can
help support each other so um I'd recommend the flow book here which is about the psychology of
optimal experience um which talks about this model the other thing that I think about
a lot with the people that I have is about how do I maximize their potential um and I have this I I I've recently
sort of handed over my uh Tech lead responsibility to another developer on my team so I could go back to just being a developer which is wonderful um and
one of the models that I wrote down for him was this one that we talked about so when I'm thinking about a person there's lots of different sort of elements to
them and one of the things that I'm looking for is I need to really understand where their skill sets lie so
are they really great at sort of JavaScript are they really great at um I don't know uh database type stuff are
they really great at the operations type stuff are they good for the build uh management and sort of all of that sort
of stuff at the same time I really want to understand their strengths so what where are they actually good at are they
a completer do they need are they one of those people that need to look for new things um and then what do they actually
want to achieve out of this project and then the final thing is really about their interests so what is it that
they're currently actively interested in web services or various things like that and so what I'm trying to do is really
get a profile about the team that I have and look for where The Sweet Spot of overlap is and so the only way that you
can really do this is actually by talking to everyone on the team so you need to understand them a bit more you
want to have an open dialogue about trying to understand where that all kind of works at the same time you need to
think about what things you can actually influence so so um one of the things I think about is that well with skills
actually you can help build a lot of skills with people right so you can get external people who have expertise
working with people and you can grow that sort of stuff you can uh work if you're an expert in a certain area you
can pair program with people and transfer those skills and help people grow that sort of stuff that's something
that you can actually influence a lot um you can also help sort of shape goals a
little bit maybe people have their own sort of goals but if people don't you can you know help identify what is it
that they feel passionate about um and maybe help them with that you can't do that necessarily as easily as with
skills it's a little bit smaller at the same time also about interests so there
are tasks in development that we all need to kind of do um and it may not always be interesting to people but you
might be able to explain to somebody why it's important for Success so you know it's great that we actually wrote a new
feature but what's important is that getting live so everyone has to take part in actually getting our code
shipped into production um because that's really important right but maybe people don't like that so you
can help people understand the importance of things but once again it's a very small thing that you can influence not as much as uh skills and
unfortunately you can't really do anything about strengths so in the strengths finer book it's the the kind of just something that we're kind of
built with the things that we like um you can't really influence that so much but the things that you can do are
you can help support learning and have lots of different activities for doing this sort of stuff so some of the things
that I like doing with uh different people um obviously pair programming is a a really great thing if you're doing
sort of XP I find it really a great way of learning different techniques and things and spreading stuff around the
team um who's heard of brown bag sessions okay good but so basically we
have kind of lunchtime sessions where somebody might do a talk and on our current project we seem to be doing one every fortnite and we rotate everyone
through it and everyone just talks about their pet personal project or what things that they're actually passionate about um and then I work with them uh
for to help support them in sort of preparing their presentations and talking to people about it um I know
that some teams do like video or book clubs so maybe you have a book and you're reading a chapter a week and then
you get together and talk about well what does demain driven design have for us in this sort of Team context um or
perhaps you watch like a a 10-minute uh info que video um and then discuss how
is that applicable to what we have um some of the things I've been experimenting with lately are things
like technical uh or Spike showcases um so we we maybe have heard about
showcases in an agile iterative sense where we showcase here are all the different features um in our sort of
product that we've built uh in this sort of uh cycle but maybe one of the things that we want to focus on is actually
talking about what are the different things that we've learned amongst developers and spread that knowledge as well um and it's really good when you're
working with a large team to do this kind of uh Spike showcase type stuff where actually what you're showing is some of the technical learning and

quite useful uh I've been in many a retrospective where the developers dominate just because they have a lot of
people compared to other roles and they end up talking about things like uh we don't spend enough time rotating through
pairs or the build has been broken a lot this this iteration um and so a technical Focus retrospective can
actually help Focus uh everyone on learning stuff about the codebase and what other people are concerned about uh
and it also may may lift the rest of your retrospectives so they're actually kind of useful as well and the other
thing is whole team code reviews so um I don't know if anyone does these but uh
the way that I kind of conduct them is that we have a room and then we get people to pick out different parts of the code base that they'd like to talk
about and then we project it up on the screen and then we all kind of have a bit of a go at it kind of thing uh and because we have kind of collective code
ownership there's none of this uh you know one person has ownership of this so they're not really going to be really
defensive around this sort of part if we if we inspect it and then we just talk about what are the things we'd like to
improve around this sort of stuff and then that kind of evolves in our sort of iterative code standards so as we tackle
new problems we we detect these code kind of code smells we get everyone together in a room and we project it up
and then we agree what's the best way forward of actually getting there so I think that's a really useful thing about
how we can amplify some of these learning sort of activities the final thing about um
people is that people it's really hard you know it's very uncomfortable as a developer having to think about these
kind of things and uh one of the hardest bits of advice I've had to give people is really about beware the Bad
Apple um and one of the things that I think uh is is really um contagious I
think is that we can be really hard on ourselves and we can be really negative sometimes um and maybe you've worked
with developers who are like this who have a pet have a have a pet peeve of some sort and all they do is talk about
it constantly um and maybe that starts to infect everyone else in the project and
there's an interesting psychological paper called bad is stronger than good that talks about in order to offset sort
of negative kind of uh comments of something you need 10 positive reinforcement things to offset one
negative stuff so one of the things that um I I sort of give advice to T leads
when I'm sort of coaching them when I'm working with them is bear wear the Bad Apple and there's different ways of actually dealing with this so you might
actually help them understand you know uh what how they're saying something is is the thing that's actually affecting
it or maybe they don't actually feel like they're being heard so you want to give them an opportunity to do that so
you maybe you have a a way in the technical retrospective to be able to talk about some of the problems that they're actually seeing what's important
is that you don't let somebody's stew because that sort of stuff can actually spread or the rest of the team might end
up isolating that person which isn't good for anyone it's uncomfortable for the other person it's uncomfortable for
the team uh and we need to be able to actually deal with this so I think one of the big best parts of advice is that
as a tech lead you need to actually develop skills in sort of conflict management and help people find ways of
airing the issues that they have at um that are concerning them and then find ways of overcoming that and if that
doesn't become uh if that's not a viable solution you may end up needing to recompose the team
so finally I wanted to kind of talk about the process side to teams um and
one of the questions I get a lot is is it okay to tell people what to do we kind of work in this collaborative space
now this agile stuff everyone's supposed to get along but can I tell somebody what to do and I my my advice to them is
yes but only sometimes if you're telling somebody what to do all the time there's definitely something wrong um and
there's something called the situational Leadership Model that's really useful for understanding this so they kind of
talk about do you direct people or do you support people and the different combinations uh and you go through this
weird sort of cycle graph backwards um in terms of thinking about do you do
sort of directing or coaching um supporting or
delegating and when you're thinking about this one of the things that the model kind of talks about is you really
once again need to understand where somebody is at with the task and the uh sort of skills of that person at the
time so one of the things they talk about in this model is if you have low competence but somebody's really
enthusiastic so a really good example is if you have graduates straight from University who don't have experience they're normally really enthusiastic you
know they want to program but they don't really know how they they want to learn all this stuff but they just you know they're on they're fresh on their
Journey you might need to actually be helping them and and directing them a lot more on the flip side you have
somebody who's been picking up a skill and you've probably been through this yourself where you've been doing something maybe you've started unit
testing but you're not quite comfortable with it yet so you're not really so sure of it so their their term commitment
kind of involves both confidence and motivation so maybe they're not so confident in their own skills yet and
part of this model is then thinking about you need to actually help coach that person in that situation um and then you kind of get on
to more competence but they're not really there in terms of commitment so
uh you know they understand and they're pretty competent and they they know that they're pretty good but maybe they don't understand why it's important um and
this is where you might need to be supporting them in that sort of sense and then finally you have high
competence uh and high commitment and that's basically something you can just delegate something so it's like I trust
you you can deal with this and I don't have to worry about it so that's kind of that sort of model the other thing I
think a lot a lot about is about tuckman's um and it's a very old model I think it comes from uh like 1970 um but
it's basically a study about how do how do teams form um and one of the comments that I've had from people before is that
I think people say that actually know our team's been together for a long time but I think one of the things is that
actually you have one person join or you have one person leave you have a new team you go through this model again so
when you think about it a team a group of people get together they're definitely not a team they're just starting to form and then you start to
get some conflict so you get some disagreement you get some arguing uh and then you get through if you can get
through this stage you get to some sort of normalization and and these two stages for me are really critical as a tech
lead to really support so you want to be able to embrace conflict and talk about issues openly but you need to be able to
get through that as well so that you get to norming I've seen a lot of places where people avoid conflict and they end up in this kind of storming phase and
they never ever actually get to agreeing on how do they work as a group if you ever done uh sort of Team chartering or
sort of uh project Charters this is a really useful exercise to get through this and if you can get through that
then you end up with a pretty high performing team um so you know people who understand how each other works um
and maybe once you finish a milestone you end up adjourning and I think this is something that they added on to their
model which is really good and as a tech lead you want to celebrate this part it's it's a little bit sad sometimes
because your team is kind of maybe breaking up uh or somebody is leaving but you really want to help support this
and what I really want to think about what I really want you to think about is when somebody does join or leave you can
go really D dramatically from a performing team back into a forming team so all it takes is one new person to
join a team and the whole Dynamics will shift somebody who is very loud or somebody who's very quiet who doesn't
fit in can change the entire Dynamics the same thing if somebody moves or changes positions a lot of that sort of
stuff can happen again so like a lot of these models you kind of need to be thinking about these constantly and seeing where your team's at so small
inspect and adapt and see what things you might want to try to to to help get to the next
stage and I really like this quote which is essentially all models are wrong but
some are useful so one of the things for instance that I think about here that both of these models don't cover is what
happens if you're in a very chaotic environment so you have eight different people coming at the team all the time

is the process about you and spending time for yourself I've watched a lot of team leads who end up sort of in

think one of the things that made it easy to accept how to deal with this is actually at the end of the day you can't
